results.title: Sex, guys and videotape
results.creator_credit: Martin Coombes, Mark Fitzgerald and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Elle McFeast (aka Lisbeth Gorr) presents this celebration of male sexuality with some of Australia’s pre-eminent males; Nick Giannopoulos, Greg Chappell, Lex Marinos, Mikey Robins, Hung Le, Rex Mossop, Mike Whitney, Ian Rogerson, Damien Lovelock, the Oarsome Foursome, Doug Mulray, Neil Murray, Piet Collins, Darren Baxter, Paul Hudson and Clive Robertson. Collectively, they discuss issues such as whether size really matters, self control, naming conventions, how they learnt about sex, the first time, condom wearing and what it feels like, what makes for sensational sex, performance anxiety and one night stands. Judith Lucy and Deborah Conway also contribute.

results.title: Thor: Love and Thunder
results.brief_description: Thor: Love and Thunder sees Thor (Chris Hemsworth) embark on a journey of self-discovery – which is suddenly interrupted by a galactic killer, Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale), who seeks to eliminate the gods.

constellations_other.name: Marvellous and magic MCU inventions
constellations_other.description: In Thor: Love and Thunder, the iconic weapons Mjölnir and Stormbreaker are joined by new additions like Zeu's Thunderbolt - they're just a long line of enchanted and technologically advanced weapons in movies.

constellations_other.name: Physical transformation and the formation of character
constellations_other.description: Christian Bale is hardly recogniseable as villain Gorr the God Butcher in Thor: Love and Thunder. It’s just another instance of the actor drastically changing his appearance to inhabit a character – and he’s not the only one.

constellations_other.name: Mayes C Rubeo
constellations_other.description: Emmy-award winning and Oscar-nominated costume designer Mayes C Rubeo has worked on some of Hollywood's biggest blockbusters, designing costumes for characters and creatures across time, space and everything in between.

results.description:
Thor: Love and Thunder sees Thor (Chris Hemsworth) embark on a journey of self-discovery – which is suddenly interrupted by a galactic killer, Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale), who seeks to eliminate the gods.

Thor joins forces with King Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson), Korg (Taika Waititi) and, to his surprise, ex-girlfriend Jane Foster (Natalie Portman), who now wields Mjolnir as the Mighty Thor, to understand the mystery of Gorr’s vengeance and stop him before it’s too late.

Featuring 25 costume changes for Thor alone, the film is a visual feast. “Thor’s sort of searching for his identity, and that’s represented in his wardrobe,” Chris Hemsworth reflected. “The costumes and the sets aesthetically match the energy of the film — they’re another colour to the painting.”
description_for_label:
Thor: Love and Thunder sees Thor (Chris Hemsworth) embark on a journey of self-discovery – which is suddenly interrupted by a galactic killer, Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale), who seeks to eliminate the gods.

Thor joins forces with King Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson), Korg (Taika Waititi) and, to his surprise, ex-girlfriend Jane Foster (Natalie Portman), who now wields Mjolnir as the Mighty Thor, to understand the mystery of Gorr’s vengeance and stop him before it’s too late.

Featuring 25 costume changes for Thor alone, the film is a visual feast. “Thor’s sort of searching for his identity, and that’s represented in his wardrobe,” Chris Hemsworth reflected. “The costumes and the sets aesthetically match the energy of the film — they’re another colour to the painting.”

results.title: VNS Matrix: The Cyberfeminist Manifesto for the 21st Century

constellations_other.name: Future forward; cyberpunk manifestations, fantasy and world building
constellations_other.description: Science fiction and cyberpunk are often powerful projections of the future, which may act as dystopic warnings or strive for an optimistic outcome where societies rise above adversity.

results.title_for_label: VNS Matrix: The Cyberfeminist Manifesto for the 21st Century
results.description: In 1991, VNS Matrix unleashed their collaborative manifesto A Cyberfeminist Manifesto for the 21st Century. They put it on the internet and a giant travelling billboard. From there, it quickly leaked onto the radio and magazine pages and other IRL ephemera, jumping from medium to medium at rapid pace, eventually coming to rest in the centre of a 6m x 3m billboard, flanked by speculative/fantastical icons, in the form of a futuristic sigil. It was in this gyne-canonical text that the term “cyberfeminism” first appeared.
description_for_label: In 1991, VNS Matrix unleashed their collaborative manifesto A Cyberfeminist Manifesto for the 21st Century. They put it on the internet and a giant travelling billboard. From there, it quickly leaked onto the radio and magazine pages and other IRL ephemera, jumping from medium to medium at rapid pace, eventually coming to rest in the centre of a 6m x 3m billboard, flanked by speculative/fantastical icons, in the form of a futuristic sigil. It was in this gyne-canonical text that the term “cyberfeminism” first appeared.

results.title: The Girl from Tomorrow. Ep 1-3
results.creator_credit: Noel Price, Film Australia, Nine Network and Kathy Mueller
results.brief_description: Alana, a lively 13 year old from the year 3000, finds herself stranded in a strange and primitive world when a time-travel experiment goes terribly wrong. She is kidnapped by Silverthorn, a fugitive war-lord from the dangerous and violent times of the year 2500 and they crash land in a rubbish dump in Sydney in the year 1990. Alana crawls from the battered time capsule, leaving Silverthorn unconscious, and escapes with her personal wrist computer P.J. as her only companion. Cold, hungry and frightened, she is discovered by Jenny, a rebellious purple-haired girl her own age and Petey, Jenny’s science fiction obsessed younger brother.

constellations_other.name: Retrofuturism: aesthetic impact of space design on screen culture
constellations_other.description: Humans have long imagined the future, including prospective travel to space and what living life away from planet earth could look like. This extending to designing interiors of domestic spaces and how these have then influenced the aesthetics of screen culture through set building and design.

results.title: La Vie a L'envers = Life Upside Down
results.brief_description:
An ordinary young Paris office worker suddenly decides to retreat into his own inner world, giving up his loquacious new wife, his friends, work and possessions. He ends up contentedly staring at a blank wall in the bare room of mental clinic. The theme of alienation, a prevalent one in the 1960s, has seldom been explored with such wry wit and sensitivity, although the film’s attitude to its hero remains ambiguous. Awards: Cannes Festival (1964): Critics’ Week Prize ; Venice Film Festival (1964): Prize for the First Work. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Director, Alain Jessua ; writer, Alain Jessua ; photography, Jacques Robin ; music, Jacques Loussier.
Cast: Charles Denner, Anna Gaylor, Jean Yanne, Yvonne Clech, Robert Bousquet, Nicole Gueden, Guy Saint-Jean, Francois Moncey, Jean Dewewer.
